- usually referred to locally as just
- is a market town in the county of
, England.  It is famous for the Melton Mowbray Pork Pie and as the centre of Stilton Cheese production. Melton Mowbray is also recognised as the "Rural Capital of Food".
Melton Mowbray lies about 15 miles (25km) north-east of

.

Train services are provided by East Midlands Trains and CrossCountry on the Birmingham - Leicester - Peterborough line, with services about hourly in both directions (a bit more frequently during rush hours, and a very poor service on Sundays).

Buses also go to/from Leicester, Oakham, Nottingham, Loughborough and Grantham. There are no buses in or out of Melton in the evenings or on Sundays and Bank Holidays. The main two bus companies are Arriva and Centerbus.

The town centre is fairly small and can generally be done on foot. Most of the main shops and streets are wheelchair/pram friendly.
The main shopping area is pedestrianised apart from delivery vehicles.
is a neolithic hill fort about 6 km/4miles south-east of Melton, with high ramparts and excellent views over a lot of Leicestershire.

value: directions=Take the A6006 Asfordby Road from town, Sysonby Knoll is about 1km from centre on the left

content=Traditional and modern food served in a very relaxed colonial style restaurant - not a typical hotel restaurant.  Sysonby Knoll has excellent gardens and is also open for teas/ coffees etc during the day.  Particularly popular for Sunday Lunch.
on Sherrard Street is certainly the best English/Continental restaurant in town, at quite reasonable prices.
There are three Indian Restaurants, where the quality - and service - seem to vary almost by the day;
Chinese restaurant, is recommended and very popular at weekends.
restaurant on Burton Street providing an comprehensive [if slightly expensive] menu, excellent service and tasty food.

----

Some of the best places to eat out are the pubs in nearby villages, which often use locally sourced foods.
, a celebrated group of local gourmands, include the following in their recommendations:-

actually a pub, but a collection of holiday chalets with a good restaurant attached;
content=At Burton Coggles south of Grantham - You need to order your pie in advance. The food is excellent and the host pleasantly eccentric;

has a good variety of traditional real ales and offers an excellent Sunday lunch.

The nearby
also has real ales, and live bands on Fridays and Saturdays. The bands tend to be formulaically loud.
next door to St Mary's Church is a splendid pub, the landlord Mr Trettis being the longest serving in the town. Sunday lunches are of a very high standard.

value: content=30 bedroom family run hotel and restaurant on outskirts of Melton Mowbray.
